summary_llm:
The story begins with Philip Pirrip, who calls himself Pip, an orphan living in the marsh country with his much older sister, Mrs. Joe Gargery, and her husband, Joe, the blacksmith. Pip's parents and five infant brothers are deceased, their tombstones in the local churchyard. One raw afternoon, while visiting the graves, Pip is accosted by a fearful, coarse-clothed man with an iron on his leg, an escaped convict. The convict threatens Pip with death, claiming he has a "young man" accomplice, and demands a file and food ("wittles") be brought to him early the next morning at an old battery on the marshes. Terrified, Pip agrees, fearing for his life.

Back home on Christmas Eve, Pip's guilt over the impending theft weighs heavily on him. His sister, Mrs. Joe, is a harsh woman who has raised him "by hand" (often hitting him with a cane called "Tickler"), while Joe is a kind, mild-mannered man. Joe and Pip share a bond as fellow sufferers under Mrs. Joe's temper. Pip secretly stashes his bread and butter in his trousers for the convict, which Joe notices, leading to Mrs. Joe's angry interrogation and dosing of them both with foul-tasting tar-water. That evening, Pip hears cannon fire, signifying another escaped convict from the nearby prison-ships, or "Hulks." He is plagued by thoughts of the convict and his "young man" tearing out his heart and liver. Before dawn, Pip steals bread, cheese, mincemeat, brandy, a meat bone, and a pork pie from the pantry, and a file from Joe's forge, then hurries to the misty marshes.

At the battery, Pip first encounters a different man, also a convict, who curses at him and flees. Pip realizes this must be the "young man" the first convict mentioned. Soon after, he finds his original convict, shivering and ravenous. Pip gives him the food and file. The convict devours the food, drinking the brandy Pip brought. Pip mentions seeing the other convict, startling the man, who furiously files at his own leg-iron, believing the other is pursuing him. Pip, fearing the convict's rage, slips away.

Returning home, Pip finds the robbery undiscovered, as Mrs. Joe is preoccupied with Christmas dinner preparations for guests: Mr. Wopsle (the church clerk), Mr. and Mrs. Hubble, and Uncle Pumblechook (a cornchandler and Joe's uncle). Pip feels out of place and ashamed of his commonness. During dinner, the guests repeatedly criticize Pip and his upbringing. When Pumblechook drinks the brandy Pip had refilled with tar-water, he suffers a violent, comical fit, leading Pip to believe he has poisoned him. Mrs. Joe then prepares to serve the stolen pork pie. Just as Pip realizes the pie will be discovered, soldiers arrive at the door.

The soldiers' arrival causes a commotion. The sergeant explains they need Joe to mend a pair of handcuffs for two escaped convicts. Joe, the blacksmith, agrees, and the soldiers wait. Pip is relieved the handcuffs are not for him. He overhears the sergeant discussing the search for the convicts on the marshes. Joe fixes the handcuffs. Pip, Joe, and Mr. Wopsle accompany the soldiers on the hunt. In the dark, sleety marshes, they hear shouts and eventually find the two convicts fighting in a ditch. Pip's convict boasts he caught the other and dragged him back to justice. The other convict, severely mauled, accuses Pip's convict of attempted murder. Pip's convict, Magwitch, is then taken into custody. In a hut, Magwitch confesses to stealing food and a pie from "the blacksmith's," surprising Joe, who compassionately states he is welcome to it. Magwitch is then taken to a prison-ship (Hulk).

After Magwitch's departure, Pip is tormented by guilt and shame, particularly towards Joe, whom he feels he has wronged. He fears confessing the truth would make Joe think him worse. Mrs. Joe and the guests speculate on how the convict broke into the house, with Pumblechook offering an elaborate, incorrect theory. Pip begins to learn with Biddy, Mr. Wopsle's great-aunt's granddaughter, who teaches him to read and write. Joe, who cannot read, shares his sad childhood story of an abusive, alcoholic father and how he married Mrs. Joe because she took in Pip. Pip develops a new admiration for Joe, despite his earlier embarrassment.

Pip is later informed that Miss Havisham, the eccentric lady of Satis House, wants him to return. Pumblechook takes credit for this arrangement. Pip, after a harsh scrubbing by Mrs. Joe, accompanies Pumblechook to Miss Havisham's. Estella, Miss Havisham's beautiful but scornful adopted daughter, admits only Pip, dismissing Pumblechook. Inside the decaying Satis House, Pip finds Miss Havisham, a withered lady in a faded bridal gown, whose clocks and watch are stopped at twenty minutes to nine. Miss Havisham, who has not seen daylight since her wedding day, demands Pip "play." Estella treats Pip with disdain, calling him a "common labouring-boy" with "coarse hands" and "thick boots," which makes Pip ashamed. Miss Havisham tells Pip to return in six days. Estella then gives Pip food as if he were a dog. Pip, humiliated, cries, and then has a momentary illusion of Miss Havisham hanging from a beam in the deserted brewery. He walks home, deeply dissatisfied with his life and status.

Pip continues to visit Miss Havisham every other day for many months, pushing her in a chair around her dusty rooms. She subtly encourages his admiration for Estella and frequently tells Estella to "Break their hearts." During this time, Pip also suffers the constant presence and patronizing remarks of Miss Havisham's grasping relatives (Mrs. Camilla, Cousin Raymond, Sarah Pocket, Georgiana), who resent Pip's attention. One day, Miss Havisham tells Pip he is growing too tall and should be apprenticed at once. She asks Joe to bring Pip's indentures. Mrs. Joe is enraged by this, but Joe complies. At Satis House, Joe, awkward and addressing only Pip, signs the indentures. Miss Havisham gives Pip twenty-five guineas as a premium, which Joe, addressing Pip, says he will not take for himself, as no money can compensate for losing Pip's "little child" self. Miss Havisham, as they leave, tells Joe this is Pip's reward and he should expect no more. Pip feels ashamed of Joe's commonness in Estella's presence. At Pumblechook's, Joe, with Pip's help, exaggerates the sum to Mrs. Joe and lets Pumblechook take credit for the premium. Pip is formally bound as Joe's apprentice, then attends a celebratory dinner where he is again humiliated.

Pip begins his apprenticeship at the forge, but is now ashamed of his home and trade, seeing it as "coarse and common," a direct result of Estella's influence. He imagines Estella's scorn if she saw him working. He tries to improve himself by studying with Biddy, but his heart remains set on Estella. Joe's journeyman, Orlick, resents Pip and frequently clashes with Mrs. Joe. One day, a violent quarrel erupts between Orlick and Mrs. Joe, culminating in a fight between Joe and Orlick, which Joe wins. Mrs. Joe collapses, suffering a severe blow to the back of her head, leaving her with impaired sight, hearing, memory, and speech. The weapon found nearby is a filed-asunder convict's leg-iron. Pip suspects either Orlick or the strange man who showed him the file in the Three Jolly Bargemen. Biddy comes to live with them, becoming an invaluable helper. She deduces from Mrs. Joe's slate drawings that Orlick was the assailant, signified by a crude hammer symbol. Mrs. Joe, strangely, seems to want to conciliate Orlick afterwards.

Pip continues his annual visits to Miss Havisham, receiving a guinea each time. He observes Biddy's growing intelligence and kindness, contrasting her with Estella. He confesses to Biddy his desire to be a gentleman for Estella's sake, but Biddy wisely questions his motives, suggesting Estella is "not worth gaining over." Pip is angered by Biddy's realism. He travels to London for his "great expectations." There, he meets Mr. Jaggers, his guardian, a formidable lawyer whose office is filled with strange artifacts, including casts of the faces of hanged clients. Pip also encounters Jaggers's clerk, Wemmick, who has a peculiar "post-office" mouth and separates his professional life from his private life at his "Castle" in Walworth, where he lives with his deaf "Aged Parent" and courts Miss Skiffins. Pip finds his fellow student, Herbert Pocket (the pale young gentleman he fought), in London. They become friends, and Herbert reveals Miss Havisham's tragic story: she was jilted on her wedding day by a man named Compeyson, who conspired with her half-brother Arthur to swindle her. This event led her to stop all the clocks and live in eternal mourning.

Pip learns from Herbert that he is secretly engaged to Clara Barley and dreams of becoming a capitalist to marry her. Pip also incurs significant debt, mirroring Herbert's struggles. Pip and Herbert join "The Finches of the Grove," an expensive club. Pip receives a letter from Trabb & Co. informing him of his sister, Mrs. Joe's, death. Pip returns home for the funeral, feeling remorse for his past ingratitude. Pumblechook, however, is overtly condescending and takes credit for Pip's past prosperity. Pip tells Biddy of his plan to leave Joe and marry her, only for Biddy to reveal she is marrying Joe, who has paid off Pip's debts. Heartbroken but understanding, Pip leaves. He sells his possessions, pays his creditors, and joins Herbert as a clerk in Clarriker & Co., a shipping-broker firm in Cairo. Years later, Pip becomes a partner, and Herbert learns of Pip's secret generosity in funding his initial partnership.

Eleven years pass. Pip, now an "old bachelor" and partner in the firm, returns to his hometown. He finds Joe, hale and strong, with a young son, also named Pip, sitting on Pip's old stool by the forge fire. Joe and Biddy are happily married. Pip walks with the young Pip to the churchyard, where the boy points out the family tombstones. Pip learns that Estella had led an unhappy life, separated from her cruel husband (Drummle), who died in an accident. Pip revisits the site of Satis House, now demolished, with only the garden wall remaining. He finds Estella there. Her beauty has faded, but her eyes now hold a "saddened, softened light," and her touch is friendly. Estella tells him that suffering has "bent and broken" her "into a better shape" and that she now understands his heart. They agree to be friends and continue friends apart. The story ends with Pip taking Estella's hand as they walk out of the ruined place, with the evening mists rising, and he sees "no shadow of another parting from her."

summary_llm:
This detailed summary is based exclusively on the provided text of "Hamlet, Prince of Denmark," and does not incorporate any external knowledge, literary analysis, or philosophical discussion.

**ACT I**

**Scene I: Elsinore. A Platform Before the Castle. Night.**
The play opens on a cold, bitter night on a platform before the castle at Elsinore. Francisco is on his guard post when Bernardo arrives to relieve him. Francisco expresses a feeling of being "sick at heart." Bernardo, Horatio, and Marcellus then gather. Marcellus asks Horatio if "this thing" has appeared again, but Horatio, a skeptic, dismisses it as "fantasy." Bernardo and Marcellus recount having seen an apparition twice before.

As Bernardo begins to describe the previous sightings, the Ghost appears, resembling the recently deceased King Hamlet, clad in the same warlike armor he wore when he battled Norway. Horatio is immediately struck with "fear and wonder." Urged by Marcellus, Horatio addresses the Ghost, demanding to know why it walks at night in the form of the "buried Denmark" and charges it to speak. The Ghost, however, stalks away without a word.

Horatio, now convinced of its reality, notes that its appearance bodes "some strange eruption to our state," drawing a comparison to omens seen before the fall of Julius Caesar. The Ghost re-enters. Horatio, crossing its path, commands it to speak if it has a voice, if it can perform a good deed, if it knows of the country's fate, or if it guards hidden treasure. The Ghost seems on the verge of speaking but is abruptly startled by the crowing of a cock and vanishes. Horatio explains that spirits flee at the sound of the cock, which heralds the morning. He suggests they report what they have seen to young Hamlet, believing the spirit, silent to them, will speak to his son.

**Scene II: A Room of State in the Palace.**
King Claudius, addressing his court, acknowledges the recent death of his brother, King Hamlet. Despite the lingering grief, he states that "discretion" has led him to marry Queen Gertrude, his "sometime sister, now our queen," a union he describes as a "defeated joy." He thanks the court for their concurrence in this matter.

He then grants Laertes, son of Polonius, permission to return to France, a request Polonius confirms he granted with "hard consent." Claudius turns to Hamlet, questioning his continued melancholic appearance ("How is it that the clouds still hang on you?"). Hamlet replies cryptically, "A little more than kin, and less than kind," and "I am too much i'the sun." Queen Gertrude urges Hamlet to shed his "nighted colour" and accept that death is a common human experience. Hamlet insists his sorrow is deeply felt, "I have that within which passeth show; These but the trappings and the suits of woe."

King Claudius criticizes Hamlet's "obstinate condolement" as "unmanly grief" and "impious stubbornness." He asks Hamlet to consider him as a father, reminding him that Hamlet is "the most immediate to our throne." Queen Gertrude also pleads with Hamlet to stay in Denmark and not return to Wittenberg for his studies. Hamlet reluctantly agrees to obey his mother. The King and Queen exit with their retinue.

Alone, Hamlet expresses profound despair, wishing his flesh would melt or that God's law against suicide did not exist. He finds the world "weary, stale, flat, and unprofitable," an "unweeded garden." He laments his father's death, which occurred less than two months prior, contrasting his noble father ("Hyperion to a satyr") with his "incestuous" uncle, Claudius. He is disgusted by his mother's hasty marriage to his uncle, which followed so quickly after his father's funeral that the "bak'd meats Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables." He concludes, "It is not, nor it cannot come to, good: But break, my heart, for I must hold my tongue!"

Horatio, Bernardo, and Marcellus enter. Hamlet, surprised and pleased to see Horatio, asks what brings them from Wittenberg. Horatio explains he came for King Hamlet's funeral, which Hamlet bitterly reframes as his mother's wedding. Horatio then cautiously reveals the purpose of their visit: they have seen the apparition of King Hamlet. Hamlet is incredulous and demands details. Horatio describes the armed figure, resembling the late king, seen thrice on watch. He confirms he spoke to it, but it remained silent, only motioning as if to speak before the cock crowed and it vanished. Hamlet, after confirming details of the ghost's appearance (armed, pale, sorrowful, with a "sable silver'd" beard), decides to join them on watch that night, determined to speak to the ghost "though hell itself should gape." He makes Horatio, Bernardo, and Marcellus swear to keep the sighting secret. Alone, Hamlet suspects "foul play" and resolves to await the night, believing "Foul deeds will rise, Though all the earth o'erwhelm them, to men's eyes."

**Scene III: A Room in Polonius's House.**
Laertes, preparing to embark for France, advises his sister Ophelia concerning Hamlet's declarations of love. He warns her to treat Hamlet's affections as fleeting, "a fashion, and a toy in blood," because Hamlet, as a prince, cannot choose for himself, and his choice affects the "safety and the health of the whole state." He cautions her against believing his "songs" to protect her "honour." Ophelia promises to remember his advice but playfully warns him not to be a hypocrite by treading "the primrose path of dalliance" himself.

Polonius enters and chides Laertes for his delay. He then delivers a lengthy series of precepts to Laertes: don't voice all thoughts, be selective with friends, avoid quarrels but be fierce if in one, listen more than you speak, dress well but not ostentatiously, and neither borrow nor lend. He concludes with, "This above all,--To thine ownself be true; And it must follow...Thou canst not then be false to any man." Laertes departs, reminding Ophelia of his advice.

Polonius questions Ophelia about what Laertes discussed, specifically regarding Lord Hamlet. Ophelia admits Hamlet has made "many tenders Of his affection." Polonius dismisses Hamlet's advances as disingenuous "springes to catch woodcocks" and forbids Ophelia from having any further contact or communication with Hamlet. Ophelia meekly promises to obey.

**Scene IV: The Platform. Night.**
Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus stand watch. The bitter cold is noted. From the castle, trumpets and cannon fire indicate the King's late-night revelry, which Hamlet criticizes as a custom "More honour'd in the breach than the observance." The Ghost reappears. Hamlet directly addresses it, calling it "Hamlet, King, father: Royal Dane," demanding it speak and explain its return, which makes "night hideous." The Ghost beckons Hamlet to follow it alone. Horatio and Marcellus warn Hamlet not to go, fearing it may lead him to madness or harm. Hamlet dismisses their fears, stating he values his life "not at a pin's fee" and his soul is immortal. He breaks free from their attempts to restrain him, threatening violence against anyone who hinders him, and follows the Ghost to a more remote part of the platform.

**Scene V: A More Remote Part of the Platform. Night.**
The Ghost leads Hamlet to a secluded area and bids him "Mark me." It identifies itself as Hamlet's father's spirit, currently "Doom'd for a certain term to walk the night, And for the day confin'd to fast in fires," until its earthly sins are purged. It commands Hamlet to seek revenge for its "foul and most unnatural murder." The Ghost reveals the official story—that a serpent stung him while he slept in his orchard—is a lie. The true "serpent that did sting thy father's life Now wears his crown," revealing Claudius, Hamlet's uncle, as the murderer.

The Ghost denounces Claudius as an "incestuous, that adulterate beast," who seduced Queen Gertrude with "witchcraft of his wit, with traitorous gifts," despite King Hamlet's noble love. The Ghost then describes the murder: while he slept, as was his custom in the afternoon, Claudius stole upon him and poured "juice of cursed hebenon" into his ear. This potent poison swiftly coursed through his body, depriving him "Of life, of crown, of queen, at once." He died without receiving his last rites ("Unhousel'd, disappointed, unanel'd"), sent to his final account with all his "imperfections on my head."

The Ghost urges Hamlet to act, but warns him not to "Taint not thy mind, nor let thy soul contrive Against thy mother aught: leave her to Heaven," and to the prickings of her own conscience. As dawn approaches, the Ghost fades, commanding Hamlet to "remember me." Hamlet, horrified, vows to erase all other thoughts and dedicate his memory solely to his father's command.

Horatio and Marcellus arrive, anxious for news. Hamlet's replies are disjointed and "wild and whirling words." He hints at a villain in Denmark but avoids explicit details. He makes them swear on his sword not to reveal what they have seen. The Ghost's voice from beneath the stage twice commands them to "Swear." Hamlet acknowledges the strangeness of the event, stating there are "more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, Than are dreamt of in your philosophy." He then warns them that he may "put an antick disposition on" (feign madness) and makes them swear not to give any hint that they know his behavior is feigned. Hamlet concludes with a lament: "The time is out of joint;--O cursèd spite, That ever I was born to set it right!"

**ACT II**

**Scene I: A Room in Polonius's House.**
Ophelia, deeply distressed, reports to Polonius an alarming encounter with Hamlet. She describes him entering her closet dishevelled, pale, with knocking knees and a "piteous" look. He gripped her wrist, held her at arm's length, and stared intently at her face "As he would draw it." After a long silence, he shook her arm slightly, waved his head thrice, and then sighed so profoundly it seemed "to shatter all his bulk." He then released her, backing out of the room with his eyes fixed on her until he was out of sight. Polonius, convinced, concludes Hamlet is "Mad for thy love." Ophelia confirms she has obeyed her father's command to repel Hamlet's letters and deny his access, which Polonius now believes is the cause of Hamlet's madness. Polonius decides to immediately inform the King.

**Scene II: A Room in the Castle.**
King Claudius and Queen Gertrude welcome Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, Hamlet's old friends. The King expresses concern over Hamlet's "transformation" and asks them to remain at court to observe him, cheer him, and discover the unknown cause of his affliction. They pledge their full obedience.

Polonius enters, confidently stating he has discovered "The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy." After a verbose preamble, he declares Hamlet "mad" and explains his theory. He produces a love letter from Hamlet to Ophelia, which he reads aloud, containing fervent declarations of love despite Hamlet's claim of being "ill at these numbers." Polonius reveals that he observed Hamlet's "hot love" and, without being prompted by Ophelia, instructed her to reject Hamlet's advances. He attributes Hamlet's subsequent decline—from sadness to weakness, then "lightness," and finally "madness"—to this rejected love. The King and Queen find this explanation plausible.

Polonius proposes a test: he will "loose my daughter to him" while he and the King hide to observe their interaction, hoping to confirm if Hamlet's madness is indeed rooted in love. The King agrees. As Hamlet approaches, reading, the King and Queen withdraw. Polonius confronts Hamlet. Hamlet, exhibiting erratic behavior, calls Polonius a "fishmonger" and warns him to prevent his daughter from "walk[ing] i'the sun," hinting at "conception" and a "breeder of sinners." Polonius, aside, notes, "Though this be madness, yet there's method in it." Hamlet continues with satirical remarks about old men and dismisses Polonius.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern enter. Hamlet greets them warmly but quickly discerns they were "sent for" by the King and Queen. He then confides his recent melancholy: he has lost all joy, seeing the world as a "steril promontory" and the heavens as a "foul and pestilent congregation of vapours." He marvels at "What a piece of work is man!" but declares that "man delights not me,--nor woman neither." Rosencrantz mentions that a company of players (tragedians of the city) is on their way, explaining their own amusement that Hamlet, delighting not in man, would give them "lenten entertainment" (meager welcome). Hamlet questions why these players travel, noting their decline in popular estimation since his uncle became king.

Trumpets announce the players' arrival. Polonius re-enters, excitedly announcing their presence. Hamlet continues to mock Polonius, using allusions to the biblical figure Jephthah and his daughter, which Polonius again notes as "Still harping on my daughter." The Players enter, and Hamlet greets them, commenting on the First Player's grown beard and a young actor's height. He asks for a passionate speech, specifically "Æneas' tale to Dido" and Priam's slaughter. The First Player delivers an emotional rendition, which moves Hamlet and even Polonius. Hamlet praises the player's performance and instructs Polonius to treat the players well, reminding him that they are the "abstract and brief chronicles of the time."

After Polonius exits with most of the players, Hamlet asks the First Player if they can perform "The murder of Gonzago" the following night, and if the player could learn a "dozen or sixteen lines" he would insert. The player agrees. Alone, Hamlet delivers a soliloquy, chastising himself as a "rogue and peasant slave" for his inaction and lack of emotional display compared to the player, who wept for a fictional Hecuba. He calls himself "dull and muddy-mettled," a "coward," and a "kindless villain," for not having avenged his murdered father. He then devises a plan: he will have the players perform a scene similar to his father's murder before the King. He will "observe his looks" closely, believing that if the King shows guilt ("blench"), then the Ghost was honest. He acknowledges the Ghost could be the Devil abusing his melancholy. He concludes, "The play's the thing Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king."

**ACT III**

**Scene I: A Room in the Castle.**
The King and Queen inquire of Rosencrantz and Guildenstern about Hamlet's condition. They report that Hamlet confesses to distraction but refuses to reveal its cause, maintaining a "crafty madness." They mention Hamlet's enthusiasm for the players and the arranged performance that night. Polonius confirms Hamlet's invitation for the King and Queen to attend. The King, pleased, encourages Hamlet's friends to further engage him with these diversions.

The King then dismisses Gertrude, revealing his plan: Hamlet has been privately summoned to "Affront Ophelia" as if by accident. Polonius and the King will hide as "lawful espials" to observe their interaction and determine if Hamlet's "affliction" is truly due to rejected love. Gertrude expresses hope that Ophelia's beauty will restore Hamlet to his "wonted way." She exits. Polonius instructs Ophelia to walk and read a book, using the appearance of piety to "colour Your loneliness." The King, aside, feels a pang of conscience, realizing Polonius's remark about sugar-coating evil applies to himself. Polonius hears Hamlet approaching, and he and the King conceal themselves.

Hamlet enters and delivers his famous "To be, or not to be" soliloquy. He contemplates suicide as a release from life's suffering, weighing the "slings and arrows of outrageous fortune" against taking action to end them. He considers death as sleep, but fears "what dreams may come" in the "sleep of death," which "Must give us pause." This fear, he concludes, is "the respect That makes calamity of so long life," causing individuals to endure oppression and injustice rather than ending their lives. He concludes that "conscience does make cowards of us all," leading great enterprises to falter and "lose the name of action."

Ophelia returns. Hamlet, seeing her, asks her to remember his sins in her prayers. Ophelia attempts to return "remembrances" (gifts and tokens) he once gave her. Hamlet denies ever having given them, stating that "Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind." He then questions her honesty and beauty, arguing that beauty corrupts honesty more easily than honesty can elevate beauty. He claims he once loved her, then immediately retracts it: "I loved you not." He fiercely commands her, "Get thee to a nunnery," lamenting that he himself is a "breeder of sinners" and all men are "arrant knaves." He asks where her father is, and upon learning he is "At home," declares, "Let the doors be shut upon him, that he may play the fool nowhere but in's own house." Hamlet continues his rant, accusing women of using "paintings" and affected mannerisms ("jig, you amble, and you lisp") to disguise their "wantonness." He declares, "I'll no more of't; it hath made me mad." He concludes by stating there will be "no more marriages: those that are married already, all but one, shall live; the rest shall keep as they are. To a nunnery, go." Hamlet exits.

Ophelia is left heartbroken, mourning the "noble mind...o'erthrown," seeing the "rose of the fair state" and "glass of fashion" now "Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune and harsh." The King and Polonius re-emerge. The King is unconvinced Hamlet's behavior stems from love, noting his words "was not like madness" but rather suggested "something in his soul, O'er which his melancholy sits on brood." He decides to send Hamlet "with speed to England" for "neglected tribute," hoping a change of scenery will cure him. Polonius, still clinging to his theory of rejected love, agrees to the England plan but proposes one more attempt: after the play, the Queen should "be round with him" (speak plainly) alone, while Polonius hides and listens again. If this fails to reveal the truth, then Hamlet should be sent to England or confined. The King agrees, stating, "Madness in great ones must not unwatch'd go."

**Scene II: A Room in the Same.**
Hamlet instructs a Player on the art of acting: speak "trippingly on the tongue," avoid overacting or "saw[ing] the air" with hands, and always use "temperance" even in intense passion. He criticizes actors who "tear a passion to tatters," split the "ears of the groundlings," and "out-herod Herod." He stresses that acting's purpose is "to hold...the mirror up to nature." He also admonishes clowns for improvising and making "barren spectators" laugh during serious parts of a play. The Player assures Hamlet they have reformed their ways "indifferently," but Hamlet insists on reforming "altogether." The Player exits.

Hamlet calls for Horatio and praises him as a just and composed man, immune to fortune's whims, whose "blood and judgment are so well co-mingled, That they are not a pipe for fortune's finger To sound what stop she please." Hamlet then reveals that the play about to be performed contains a scene resembling his father's murder. He instructs Horatio to keenly observe the King's reaction during this scene. If the King's "occulted guilt Do not itself unkennel," then the Ghost was a "damned ghost." They agree to combine their observations.

A march announces the arrival of the court. The King, Queen, Polonius, Ophelia, Rosencrantz, Guildenstern, and other attendants enter. The King asks Hamlet how he fares, to which Hamlet replies with nonsensical wordplay about eating air. Hamlet then asks Polonius if he ever acted in the university, and Polonius proudly recounts playing Julius Caesar and being killed by Brutus. Hamlet makes a jest about it. Hamlet declines to sit with his mother, choosing instead to lie at Ophelia's feet, making suggestive and bitter comments about his mother's quick remarriage and his father's swift forgetting. Ophelia asks about the play's meaning, and Hamlet calls it "Miching mallecho" (mischief).

The play-within-a-play begins with a Prologue. Then, a Player King and Queen enter. The Player King expresses his impending death and the Player Queen vows eternal fidelity, declaring, "None wed the second but who kill'd the first." Hamlet, aside to Horatio, comments, "That's wormwood." The Player King, in the play, acknowledges the Queen's present resolve but suggests it may change. The Player Queen vehemently swears curses upon herself if she remarries. The Player King then rests and sleeps. The Player Queen exits. Queen Gertrude comments, "The lady doth protest too much, methinks." Hamlet assures her the Player Queen will keep her word. The King asks if the play contains "no offence," to which Hamlet replies, "no offence i'the world...poison in jest." He names the play "The mouse-trap" and states it's the "image of a murder done in Vienna," where Duke Gonzago is poisoned for his estate.

Lucianus, nephew to the King in the play, enters. Hamlet explains Lucianus's role as the murderer. Lucianus pours a "leperous distilment" into the sleeping Player King's ear. At this precise moment, King Claudius cries out, "Give me some light: away!" and rushes out, followed by the entire court, leaving only Hamlet and Horatio. Hamlet is ecstatic, declaring, "O, good Horatio, I'll take the ghost's word for a thousand pounds. Didst perceive?" Horatio confirms he "did very well note him" during the poisoning.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern return, reporting the King is "marvellous distempered" and the Queen is in "great affliction," desiring to speak with Hamlet in her closet. Hamlet agrees. He then berates his friends for trying to "play upon me" like a pipe, to "pluck out the heart of my mystery," asserting, "Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, you cannot play upon me." Polonius enters, again summoning Hamlet to his mother. Hamlet further mocks Polonius by asking him to describe a cloud, which Polonius quickly changes from a camel to a weasel to a whale, agreeing with Hamlet's every suggestion. Hamlet notes, "They fool me to the top of my bent." He agrees to come to his mother "by and by." Alone, Hamlet feels the "witching time of night," capable of "bitter business." He reaffirms his resolve to "speak daggers" to his mother but to use "none," remembering the Ghost's command.

**Scene III: A Room in the Same.**
King Claudius, alone with Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, states he finds Hamlet's madness dangerous and plans to send him "to England" with them immediately, with "commission" for Hamlet's "speedy voyage," to contain "this fear." Rosencrantz and Guildenstern readily agree. Polonius enters, confirming Hamlet is going to his mother's closet and reiterating his plan to hide "Behind the arras" to overhear their conversation, believing the Queen will "tax him home" (reprimand him severely). He exits to hide. The King exits.

**Scene III: The Queen's Chamber.**
Queen Gertrude and Polonius are in her chamber. Polonius advises the Queen to be direct with Hamlet about his "pranks." He then hides behind the arras. Hamlet enters. A heated exchange ensues between Hamlet and his mother. Hamlet accuses her of offending his true father, while she accuses him of offending his "father" (Claudius). When she asks if he has forgotten her, Hamlet asserts she is the queen, his "husband's brother's wife," and his mother. When she threatens to send others to speak to him, Hamlet forcefully makes her sit, declaring he will "set you up a glass Where you may see the inmost part of you." The Queen, alarmed, cries "Help, help, ho!" Polonius, from behind the arras, echoes "What, ho! help!" Hamlet, thinking it's the King, cries "How now! a rat?" and impulsively stabs through the arras, killing Polonius.

The Queen is horrified. Hamlet, returning, asks, "Is it the king?" He then confronts her about her "rash and bloody deed," calling it "almost as bad...As kill a king, and marry with his brother." The Queen, shocked, asks, "As kill a king!" Hamlet confirms, "Ay, lady, 'twas my word." Hamlet then addresses Polonius's dead body, calling him a "wretched, rash, intruding fool," admitting he "took thee for thy better." He turns back to his mother, condemning her marriage as an act that "blurs the grace and blush of modesty" and makes "marriage vows As false as dicer's oaths." He shows her two pictures, one of his noble father ("Hypérion's curls; the front of Jove himself") and one of Claudius, whom he describes as a "mildew'd ear, Blasting his wholesome brother." He questions how she could descend from such a man to "batten on this moor."

The Queen is deeply affected, confessing, "O, Hamlet! thou hast cleft my heart in twain." Hamlet continues his indictment, calling Claudius a "murderer and a villain," a "cutpurse of the empire," and "A king Of shreds and patches." The Ghost of King Hamlet reappears, visible only to Hamlet. Hamlet questions its purpose, acknowledging he has been "laps'd in time and passion" regarding his command. The Ghost states it comes "but to whet thy almost blunted purpose" and urges Hamlet to comfort his mother. The Queen, unable to see the Ghost, believes Hamlet is mad, speaking to "vacancy." Hamlet tries to describe the Ghost to her, but she sees nothing. The Ghost exits. Hamlet confirms it was his father "in his habit as he lived!" The Queen insists Hamlet's vision is a "bodiless creation ecstasy" (madness). Hamlet refutes this, demonstrating his sanity by rationally repeating his accusations. He urges her to "Confess yourself to heaven; Repent what's past; avoid what is to come." He advises her to "throw away the worser part" of her heart and "live the purer." He warns her, "go not to my uncle's bed; Assume a virtue, if you have it not." Hamlet expresses repentance for killing Polonius and promises to "answer well The death I gave him." The Queen exits. Hamlet exits, taking Polonius's body, stating, "I must be cruel, only to be kind: Thus bad begins, and worse remains behind."

**ACT IV**

**Scene I: A Room in the Castle.**
King Claudius demands from the Queen what has happened with Hamlet. The Queen, in a state of agitation, reports that Hamlet is "Mad as the sea and wind," and in a "lawless fit," killed Polonius, mistaking him for a rat behind the arras. The King expresses regret, realizing he himself could have been the victim, and worries about the public reaction to this "heavy deed," which they must "countenance and excuse." He immediately summons Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, ordering them to find Hamlet, speak to him "fair," and bring Polonius's body to the chapel. The King tells Gertrude he will gather their wisest friends to discuss how to manage the situation. He laments that they cannot punish Hamlet severely due to the "distracted multitude" who love him and judge by appearance rather than the actual offense. Rosencrantz returns, unable to get Hamlet to reveal the body's location. The King orders Hamlet brought before him.

Hamlet, accompanied by Guildenstern and Attendants, enters. The King asks where Polonius is. Hamlet replies mockingly that Polonius is "At supper," being eaten by "politick worms." He tells the King to send a messenger to heaven to find him, or to seek him in "the other place" himself, adding that within a month he will be found by smell. The King orders Guildenstern to search. The King then informs Hamlet that, for his "especial safety," he must immediately embark "For England." Hamlet agrees, bidding farewell to his "dear mother" (referring to the King, stating "Father and mother is man and wife; man and wife is one flesh; and so, my mother"). Hamlet exits for England. The King commands Rosencrantz and attendants to ensure Hamlet is swiftly put aboard the ship. Alone, King Claudius reveals his true purpose: he has sent secret "letters conjuring to that effect" to England, demanding "The present death of Hamlet." He hopes this act will bring him peace.

**Scene II: A Room in the Castle.**
Queen Gertrude is reluctant to speak with Ophelia, who is "importunate; indeed, distract." Horatio advises it would be prudent to speak with her to prevent her from spreading "dangerous conjectures." Ophelia enters, singing disjointed, sorrowful songs about a lost love, death, and a white shroud, revealing her madness. The King enters and observes her. Ophelia sings about Saint Valentine's Day and a maid who "Never departed more." She distributes symbolic flowers: rosemary for remembrance and pansies for thoughts (to Laertes, who enters), fennel for flattery and columbines (to the King), and rue for sorrow, both for herself and, "with a difference," for the Queen (suggesting repentance). She mentions violets withered when her father died. Ophelia exits, still singing and wishing "Heaven 'a mercy on his soul!"

Laertes, devastated by his sister's madness, exclaims, "O rose of May!" and wishes her sanity could inspire revenge. The King notes that "One woe doth tread upon another's heel," referring to Polonius's death and Ophelia's madness. Marcellus enters, warning the King that "The young Laertes, in a riotous head," has returned from France, leading a rebellion and inciting the rabble to cry, "Laertes shall be king!" Laertes, armed and followed by Danes, bursts in, demanding his father from the King. The Queen attempts to calm him, but Laertes fiercely declares his fury, stating that any calm blood in him would brand him a bastard. The King, trusting in his divine protection, allows Laertes to approach. Laertes demands to know where his father is. The King states he is "Dead," and the Queen quickly adds, "But not by him." Laertes, rejecting allegiance, vows to be "reveng'd Most throughly for my father." The King promises to prove his innocence and grief, and to ensure that "where the offence is let the great axe fall."

Bernardo enters with letters from Hamlet, one for the King and one for the Queen. The King reads Hamlet's letter, which announces his unexpected return, stating he is "set naked on your kingdom" and will beg leave to see the King tomorrow to explain his "sudden and more strange return." A postscript specifies "alone." The King and Laertes are bewildered. Laertes, however, is invigorated by the news, eager to confront Hamlet. The King, seeing an opportunity, asks Laertes if he will be "rul'd by me," not to peace. Laertes agrees, provided it does not lead to peace. The King then recalls a Norman gentleman who highly praised Laertes' fencing skill, especially with a rapier. He claims Hamlet was envious and wished for Laertes' return to fence with him. The King proposes a plot: they will arrange a fencing match, where Hamlet, being "remiss, Most generous, and free from all contriving," will not inspect the foils. This will allow Laertes to choose an "unbated" (unblunted) and sharpened sword, and "in a pass of practice, Requite him for your father." Laertes enthusiastically agrees, adding that he has a potent poison, an "unction of a mountebank," to anoint his sword point, ensuring death even from a mere scratch. The King further devises that if Laertes fails, he will prepare a poisoned "chalice" for Hamlet to drink during the match.

The Queen enters, bringing another sorrowful report: Ophelia has drowned. She describes Ophelia weaving "fantastick garlands" by a brook, climbing a willow tree, and how a branch broke, sending her into the "weeping brook." Ophelia, singing "snatches of old tunes," seemed oblivious to her danger until her clothes, heavy with water, pulled her "to muddy death." Laertes is overcome with grief but forces back his tears, stating he has "a speech of fire, that fain would blaze, But that this folly drowns it." He exits, followed by the King and Queen.

**ACT V**

**Scene I: A Church Yard.**
Two Clowns (gravediggers) are digging a grave. They debate whether Ophelia, having "wilfully seeks her own salvation" (committed suicide), deserves a Christian burial. The First Clown, through convoluted and comically misapplied legal arguments, asserts that the "crowner" (coroner) has ruled it a Christian burial. The Second Clown reveals that only her status as a "gentlewoman" allowed this, as otherwise she would have been buried in unsanctified ground. The First Clown laments that "great folks should have countenance" to take their own lives more easily than common people. They then engage in a riddle about who builds stronger than a mason, shipwright, or carpenter. After the Second Clown guesses "the gallows-maker," the First Clown reveals the answer: a "grave-maker," whose "houses...last till doomsday." The Second Clown is sent to fetch liquor.

Hamlet and Horatio enter and observe the First Clown singing while he digs and throws up skulls. Hamlet reflects on the skulls, imagining one to be a politician's, another a lawyer's, musing on the ultimate equality of death. He engages the gravedigger in conversation, asking whose grave it is. The Clown, with more wordplay, claims it's his. Hamlet asks how long he has been a gravedigger. The Clown replies that he started on the day King Hamlet defeated Fortinbras, which was also "the very day that young Hamlet was born," and that he has been a sexton for thirty years. This reveals Hamlet's age to be thirty. The Clown then produces a specific skull, identifying it as Yorick's, the king's jester, who has been dead twenty-three years. Hamlet takes the skull, recalling Yorick as a "fellow of infinite jest" who carried him on his back as a child. He laments the horrifying transformation of Yorick's once vibrant face and reflects on the transience of life, stating that "Imperial Cæsar, dead and turn'd to clay, Might stop a hole to keep the wind away."

Hamlet and Horatio conceal themselves as a funeral procession approaches with "maimèd rites." Laertes, the King, Queen, and mourners follow the corpse of Ophelia. Laertes questions the Priest about the abbreviated ceremony. The Priest explains that because her death was "doubtful" (suspected suicide), she would have been denied Christian burial entirely were it not for "great command" (the King's intervention). He states they cannot sing a "requiem" for her. Laertes, enraged, curses the "churlish priest," proclaims that violets will spring from Ophelia's "unpolluted flesh," and declares she will be a "ministering angel" while the priest howls in hell. Hamlet, realizing it is Ophelia's funeral, is overcome. The Queen scatters flowers on the grave, expressing her wish that Ophelia had been Hamlet's wife and that she had decked her bridal bed, not her grave. Laertes, in a fit of passionate grief, leaps into the grave, demanding to be buried with his sister.

Hamlet emerges from hiding, questioning whose exaggerated grief this is, and declares, "this is I, Hamlet the Dane." Laertes leaps from the grave and grapples with Hamlet, cursing him. Hamlet, asserting his own dangerous nature despite not being "splenetive and rash," demands Laertes release him. The King and Queen command them to be separated. Hamlet fiercely declares his love for Ophelia, stating, "forty thousand brothers Could not...Make up my sum." He challenges Laertes to prove his grief through weeping, fighting, fasting, or tearing himself. The Queen attributes Hamlet's outburst to madness. Hamlet exits, saying, "Let Hercules himself do what he may, The cat will mew, and dog will have his day." The King sends Horatio to follow Hamlet and reminds Laertes of their plot to avenge his father. He states, "This grave shall have a living monument," likely referring to Hamlet's impending death.

**Scene II: Hall in the Castle.**
Hamlet tells Horatio he regrets his outburst towards Laertes, recognizing that Laertes' grief for his father mirrors his own. Osric, an effeminate courtier, enters and delivers a message from the King: the King has wagered on a fencing match between Hamlet and Laertes. Osric, in an affected manner, praises Laertes as an "absolute gentleman," "the card or calendar of gentry." He details the wager: six Barbary horses from the King against six French rapiers and poignards from Laertes for a dozen passes, with the King wagering Laertes will not exceed Hamlet by three hits. Hamlet agrees to the match, joking about the affected language, and states he will attempt to win for the King. Osric exits to convey Hamlet's acceptance. Horatio expresses a foreboding feeling that Hamlet will lose. Hamlet admits to a "gain-giving" (misgiving) in his heart but dismisses it as "foolery," stating, "Not a whit, we defy augury: there is a special providence in the fall of a sparrow." He accepts his fate.

**Scene III: Room in the Castle.**
The King, Queen, Laertes, Osric, Lords, Ladies, and attendants gather for the fencing match. Hamlet enters with Horatio. Hamlet sincerely apologizes to Laertes for his recent behavior, attributing it to his "madness" and likening it to shooting "my arrow o'er the house, And hurt my brother." Laertes accepts the apology on a personal level but states his honor prevents him from fully reconciling until a more formal judgment is rendered. They proceed with the match. Hamlet jokes about being Laertes' "foil" to highlight Laertes' skill. The King confirms the wager. He orders wine brought and declares that if Hamlet scores the first or second hit, or answers the third, cannons will fire, and he will drink to Hamlet's health, dropping a valuable "union" (pearl) into the cup.

The match begins. Hamlet scores the first hit. Osric confirms it. The King orders the cup brought to Hamlet, but Hamlet defers drinking until after the next bout. Hamlet scores a second hit. Laertes admits, "A touch, a touch, I do confess." The Queen, against the King's subtle warning, takes the poisoned cup and drinks to Hamlet's fortune. The King, aside, realizes, "It is the poison'd cup; it is too late." Laertes, aside, states he will hit Hamlet now, despite it being "almost against my conscience." Hamlet urges Laertes to stop "dallying" and use his "best violence." They play the third pass. Laertes wounds Hamlet with the poisoned rapier. In the ensuing scuffle, they exchange rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes with the same poisoned blade.

The Queen falls back, crying, "The drink, the drink!--O, my dear Hamlet,--The drink, the drink! I am poison'd." She is carried off, dying. Hamlet, realizing treachery, orders the doors locked and demands the "villainy" be found. Laertes falls, confessing the entire plot: Hamlet is "slain," no medicine can save him as he has less than half an hour to live, and the "treacherous instrument" (the poisoned, unbated rapier) is now in Hamlet's hand. He reveals that "the foul practice Hath turn'd itself on me," and further states, "Thy mother's poison'd: I can no more: the king, the king's to blame." Hamlet, upon hearing this, cries, "Then, venom, to thy work," and stabs the King, calling him "incestuous, murd'rous, damnèd Dane," and commands him to "Follow my mother." The King is borne away, mortally wounded. Laertes, dying, exchanges forgiveness with Hamlet, absolving him of his and his father's deaths. Laertes dies.

Hamlet, also dying, says, "Heaven make thee free of it! I follow thee." He then implores Horatio, who is attempting to drink the remaining poison from the cup, to live and "Absènt thee from felicity awhile, And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain, To tell my story," so that his "wounded name" may be cleared. Hamlet's last words are, "The potent poison quite o'er-crows my spirit; The rest is silence." He dies. The curtain descends slowly.

summary_llm:
The narrative begins with a young orphan named Jane Eyre, living with her aunt, Mrs. Reed, and her cousins, Eliza, John, and Georgiana, at Gateshead Hall. It is a cold, rainy day, and Jane is excluded from the family circle by the fire. Mrs. Reed criticizes Jane's disposition and manners. Jane retreats to a window-seat in the breakfast-room, immersing herself in a book with pictures. Her cousin John Reed soon discovers her, verbally abuses her, and then physically strikes her with the book, causing her head to bleed. In a sudden fit of anger, Jane retaliates, calling John a "murderer" and "slave-driver." Mrs. Reed, alerted by the other children, orders Jane to be locked in the red-room, a seldom-used chamber where Mr. Reed (Jane's deceased uncle and Mrs. Reed's late husband) died.

Trapped in the red-room, Jane reflects on the constant abuse she endures, contrasting it with the indulgence her cousins receive. She recalls that her uncle, Mr. Reed, had made his wife promise to raise Jane as one of her own children. Overwhelmed by fear and a perceived ghostly presence (her own reflection, but also a mysterious light and sound), Jane screams, drawing the attention of Bessie (the nurse) and Miss Abbot (the maid). Mrs. Reed arrives, chastises them, and insists Jane remain locked up longer. Jane pleads for mercy, but Mrs. Reed, viewing her as a manipulative child, locks her back in, causing Jane to lose consciousness.

Jane wakes in her own bed, attended by Bessie and Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary. Mr. Lloyd assesses her condition and promises to return. Jane overhears Bessie and the housemaid, Sarah, discussing Jane's "fit" and the "Missis" being "too hard." Jane later learns from Bessie that her parents died of typhus and her mother was disinherited for marrying a poor clergyman. Mr. Lloyd suggests Jane needs a change of scene and asks if she would like to go to school. Jane, feeling miserable and isolated, eagerly agrees. Mrs. Reed, eager to be rid of Jane, accepts the recommendation.

Jane prepares to leave Gateshead for Lowood School. She refuses to bid Mrs. Reed farewell, stating her aunt has been a "foe." On January 19th, she departs by coach for the distant town of Millcote. During the journey, she is apprehensive. She is eventually met by a servant and taken to Lowood, a large, austere institution for orphans. There, she meets Miss Temple, the kind and intelligent superintendent, and Miss Miller, an under-teacher.

Life at Lowood is harsh. The girls endure bitter cold, frozen washing water, and meager, often burnt, porridge for meals. Jane struggles with the strict rules and difficult lessons. She befriends Helen Burns, a patient and deeply spiritual girl who is constantly chastised and physically punished by Miss Scatcherd for minor faults. Jane is enraged by this injustice, but Helen preaches endurance, forgiveness, and faith in God. Jane tells Miss Temple her history, and Miss Temple, believing her, writes to Mr. Lloyd, who corroborates Jane's account. Miss Temple publicly clears Jane's name, bringing Jane relief and acceptance among her peers. Jane excels in her studies, learning French and drawing.

A typhus epidemic sweeps through Lowood, killing many girls. During this time, rules relax, and the remaining healthy girls, including Jane, enjoy more freedom and better food. Helen Burns falls ill with consumption. Jane, unaware of the severity of consumption, continues her studies and enjoys the spring. She learns from a nurse that Helen is dying. Jane secretly visits Helen at night, and they share a tender conversation about faith and the afterlife. Helen dies peacefully in Jane's arms.

Eight years pass. Lowood undergoes reforms after a public inquiry exposes its deplorable conditions. Jane spends six years as a pupil and two as a teacher. Miss Temple marries and leaves, prompting Jane to desire a new life. She advertises for a governess position and receives a reply from a Mrs. Fairfax at Thornfield Hall. Before leaving Lowood, Bessie visits Jane, informing her of Mrs. Reed's terminal illness and the self-destructive lives of John, Eliza, and Georgiana Reed. Bessie also mentions that Jane's uncle, John Eyre, had sought her out years ago, intending to adopt her.

Jane travels to Thornfield Hall, where she is warmly received by Mrs. Fairfax, the kind housekeeper. She learns her pupil, Adèle Varens, is Mr. Rochester's ward. Jane also discovers a strange, recurring, mirthless laugh from the third storey, which Mrs. Fairfax attributes to a servant named Grace Poole. Jane finds Adèle a lively but undisciplined pupil.

One evening, while out posting a letter, Jane encounters a horseman who has fallen on ice. She assists him, and later discovers he is Mr. Rochester, the master of Thornfield. Mr. Rochester is a moody, enigmatic man. He invites Jane and Adèle to tea, where he interrogates Jane, praising her intellect and artistic talent, but also teasing her about her "plainness." He confesses to a past of dissolution and a desire for "fresh pleasure," speaking enigmatically of an "error" he committed. Jane, falling in love with him, hides her feelings.

A party of fashionable guests arrives at Thornfield, including the beautiful and haughty Blanche Ingram, whom Mrs. Fairfax believes Mr. Rochester intends to marry. Jane observes Mr. Rochester's close attention to Blanche, feeling both pain and a sense of inferiority, but she is not jealous, as she finds Blanche superficial and unkind. During a charade party, Mr. Rochester disguises himself as a gipsy fortune-teller and "reads" Jane's fortune, subtly probing her feelings for him and revealing his true intention was to make her jealous. He also tells Blanche Ingram her fortune, hinting at his true financial status, which makes Blanche look "wondrous grave." Jane realizes Mr. Rochester was feigning interest in Blanche.

The same night, a stranger named Mr. Mason arrives from the West Indies. Mr. Rochester reacts with extreme agitation upon hearing his name. Later that night, Jane hears a terrifying shriek and struggle from the third floor. Mr. Rochester calms the household, attributing it to a servant's nightmare, but he then secretly enlists Jane's help. He leads her to a hidden room on the third floor, where Mr. Mason lies wounded and bleeding, having been bitten and stabbed by a woman. Mr. Rochester instructs Jane to tend to Mason, forbidding her to speak to him, and then leaves to fetch a surgeon. Jane discovers that Grace Poole is the attendant for this mysterious, violent woman.

The surgeon, Carter, arrives and treats Mason, who murmurs that "she bit me" and "worried me like a tigress." Mr. Rochester implies that Mason should have been more careful. Mr. Rochester then ensures Mason is quickly and discreetly taken away. Afterward, Mr. Rochester explains to Jane his past: he was forced into a marriage in Jamaica with Bertha Mason, who was already insane and from a mad family. He brought her to Thornfield, confining her to prevent public scandal, and had intended to commit bigamy by marrying Jane. He claims he loves Jane and wants her to be his wife, not his mistress. Jane is horrified by the revelation of his existing marriage and refuses to be his mistress, asserting her principles and independent will. She tells him she must leave him.

On the eve of what was to be their wedding, Jane flees Thornfield Hall. She walks to Whitcross, destitute and starving. After two days of wandering, she collapses on the doorstep of a house called Moor House, where she is found by Mr. St. John Rivers. He and his sisters, Diana and Mary, take her in, nursing her back to health. Jane, using the alias "Jane Elliott," tells them a partial story of her past. She soon discovers that St. John, Diana, and Mary are her cousins; their uncle, John Eyre, had died in Madeira and left his entire fortune of twenty thousand pounds to "his brother the clergyman’s orphan daughter"—Jane.

Jane insists on dividing the inheritance equally among the four cousins, giving each five thousand pounds. St. John initially resists, but Jane is resolute, desiring genuine family connection over wealth. The matter is settled by arbitration.

Jane takes a position as a schoolmistress in Morton, a village near Moor House, teaching poor girls. St. John, a zealous clergyman, reveals his ambition to become a missionary in India. He falls in love with Rosamond Oliver, a beautiful local heiress, but suppresses his feelings, believing she is not suited to be a missionary's wife. Rosamond eventually marries another. St. John then asks Jane to marry him and accompany him to India as his helpmeet, arguing it is God's will and that she is "formed for labour, not for love." Jane almost yields to his powerful influence and sense of duty, but then she hears a voice, "Jane! Jane! Jane!" which she recognizes as Mr. Rochester's, speaking in pain. This spiritual summons confirms her decision to seek out Mr. Rochester. She refuses St. John's proposal, but offers to go with him as a fellow-missionary, which he rejects unless she is his wife. Jane resolves to find Mr. Rochester.

Jane returns to Whitcross and learns from the innkeeper that Thornfield Hall burned down. The innkeeper reveals that Bertha Mason, Mr. Rochester's mad wife, set the fire and then committed suicide by jumping from the roof. Mr. Rochester, in his attempt to save her, was severely injured: one eye was knocked out, a hand crushed and amputated, and the other eye inflamed, leaving him blind and crippled. He now lives in seclusion at Ferndean Manor with old John and his wife.

Jane immediately travels to Ferndean. She finds Mr. Rochester blind, mutilated, and desolate. Pilot, his dog, recognizes her, alerting Mr. Rochester to her presence. He recognizes her voice and touch, and is overwhelmed with joy. Jane reveals her new fortune and her desire to stay with him, to be his companion, nurse, and eyes. She teases him about his looks, and he playfully responds. She describes St. John Rivers, making Mr. Rochester jealous, which Jane enjoys as it lifts his melancholy. Mr. Rochester asks her to marry him, a "poor blind man," a "crippled man." Jane accepts, confirming her love for him.

Mr. Rochester recounts hearing Jane's voice calling him near midnight, the same time Jane heard his voice. He believes their souls met. He thanks God for tempering judgment with mercy, believing his past sins and afflictions have led him back to Jane.

They have a quiet wedding with only the parson and clerk present. Jane informs her cousins, Diana and Mary, who approve, and St. John, who does not respond directly. Jane retrieves Adèle from her strict school and places her in a more suitable one, eventually making her a pleasing companion.

Ten years later, Jane writes the conclusion. She and Mr. Rochester are supremely happy in their marriage. Mr. Rochester regained sight in one eye two years into their marriage. He can now see dimly and recognized his first-born son, who inherited his own eyes. Diana and Mary Rivers are both happily married. St. John Rivers went to India as a missionary, sacrificing personal happiness for his calling. He remains unmarried, working tirelessly, and Jane expects to hear of his death soon, but knows he anticipates his "incorruptible crown" in heaven.
